nodes.body:
~~`Computability.AkraBazzi` errors with ...~~

EDIT: Now fixed

Here's a simpler test-case:
```lean
example (s : Finset (ℕ)) : 0 ≤ ∑ j in s, j := by positivity  --ok
example (s : Finset (ℕ)) : 0 ≤ s.sum id := by positivity -- fails
```
I pushed an attempt at a fix, we beta expand if the f is not already a lambda

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#10538~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#10875~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
LGTM! :)
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/a17b8051-d737-4efb-a0ec-fa37ee56a246) for commit e6a642de1e8d994d20324763198ae24a3358e86e.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/0d0ee25a-d221-4362-9ac8-2724871ae485/to/a17b8051-d737-4efb-a0ec-fa37ee56a246) against commit d5a796bf260a81e8f626fd9bfe3e4c7da5c61c61.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8993536697/job/24705494384)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8993536697/job/24705494717)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8993536697/job/24705495082)

Love how much can be replaced with `by positivity` due to this PR! :)

This review is shorter than it appears: almost all of these 12 comments are about `$`, with only a couple potentially "meaningful" review comments.
Looks good with @thorimur's comments. (I am neutral about the `<|` vs `$` issue, but the style guide takes precedence.) @robertylewis, any suggestions or shall we delegate it to @thorimur?
leanprover/lean4#3126
Referenced
This is unused
This `let` should be inside the `match`.

I'm not sure why you say "should". Are both spellings not functionally equivalent? Anyway, moving it doesn't work:
```
        match s with
        | ~q(@univ _ $fi) => do
          let _no ← synthInstanceQ q(Nonempty $ι) -- failed to infer binder type
          return some q(Finset.univ_nonempty (α := $ι))
```
but that may be a bug.

> Are both spellings not functionally equivalent?

No, because the other order avoids doing a pointless typeclass search if the set was not `univ`. Probably adding an explicit annotation to `_no` fixes the error.
What do you mean by "adding an explicit annotation to `-no`"? I've tried several things, but none worked.
Oh, your problem is maybe that you can't use `return` here, it breaks Qq. Try pure instead?

The following fails still:
```
        match s with
        | ~q(@univ _ $fi) => do
          let no : Q(Nonempty $ι) ← synthInstanceQ q(Nonempty $ι)
          pure (some q(@Finset.univ_nonempty $ι $fi $no))
```
The errors are different though:
```
don't know how to synthesize implicit argument
  @synthInstanceQ
    ((let x := e;
      fun alt alt_1 x_1 u_1 ι instα s f match_eq __discr lhs fst rhs ↦
      let x := s;
      fun alt_2 alt_3 x_2 fi match_eq ↦ Level.zero)
      alt✝³ alt✝² x✝² u_1 ι instα s f match_eq✝¹ __discr✝ lhs fst✝ rhs alt✝¹ alt✝ x✝ fi match_eq✝)
    q(Nonempty «$ι»)
context:
ι✝: Type u_1
α✝: Type u_2
β: Type u_3
M: Type u_4
N: Type u_5
G: Type u_6
k: Type u_7
R: Type u_8
u: Level
α: Q(Type u)
zα: Q(Zero «$α»)
pα: Q(PartialOrder «$α»)
e: Q(«$α»)
x✝³: Q(«$α») := e
alt✝³alt✝²: MetaM (Strictness zα pα e)
x✝²: Level × Expr × Expr × Expr × Expr × Bool
u_1: Level
ι: Q(Type u_1)
instα: Q(AddCommMonoid «$α»)
s: Q(Finset «$ι»)
f: Q(«$ι» → «$α»)
match_eq✝¹: «$e» =Q Finset.sum «$s» «$f»
lhs: Array Expr
fst✝: Array BinderInfo
rhs: Q(«$α»)
x✝¹: Q(Finset «$ι») := s
alt✝¹alt✝: MetaM (Option Q(«$s».Nonempty))
x✝: Expr × Bool
fi: Q(Fintype «$ι»)
match_eq✝: «$s» =Q univ
⊢ Level
```
and
```
don't know how to synthesize implicit argument
  @bind MetaM Monad.toBind Q(Nonempty «$ι») (Option Q(«$s».Nonempty)) (synthInstanceQ q(Nonempty «$ι»)) fun no ↦
    pure (some q(_))
context:
ι✝: Type u_1
α✝: Type u_2
β: Type u_3
M: Type u_4
N: Type u_5
G: Type u_6
k: Type u_7
R: Type u_8
u: Level
α: Q(Type u)
zα: Q(Zero «$α»)
pα: Q(PartialOrder «$α»)
e: Q(«$α»)
x✝³: Q(«$α») := e
alt✝³alt✝²: MetaM (Strictness zα pα e)
x✝²: Level × Expr × Expr × Expr × Expr × Bool
u_1: Level
ι: Q(Type u_1)
instα: Q(AddCommMonoid «$α»)
s: Q(Finset «$ι»)
f: Q(«$ι» → «$α»)
match_eq✝¹: «$e» =Q Finset.sum «$s» «$f»
lhs: Array Expr
fst✝: Array BinderInfo
rhs: Q(«$α»)
x✝¹: Q(Finset «$ι») := s
alt✝¹alt✝: MetaM (Option Q(«$s».Nonempty))
x✝: Expr × Bool
fi: Q(Fintype «$ι»)
match_eq✝: «$s» =Q univ
⊢ Type
```
This looks risky if you have `f := fun {ohno} (x) => ohno`; though I suspect this is not the right approach anyway.
Sorry I'm not sure I understand your example can you elaborate on that the issue would be?
`f := fun {ohno} (x) => ohno` can't happen as an argument to `Finset.sum`?

> can you elaborate on that the issue would be?

`$f x` assumes that the argument to `f` is explicit



> `f := fun {ohno} (x) => ohno` can't happen as an argument to `Finset.sum`?

Isn't `Finset.sum univ fun {ohno : ℕ} (x : ℕ) => ohno` legal?

Oh sure, but in your example `(fun {ohno : ℕ} (x : ℕ) => ohno) 1` is just id in function space, which seems like it would work fine.
If you can come up with a realistic mw `example` I'll try and fix, but I can't really think of any myself.
I don't know what you mean by it being `id`; it's not a function at all  `(fun {ohno : ℕ} (x : ℕ) => ohno) 1 : ℕ`, and it reduces to `?ohno : ℕ` with an unresolved metavariable
`Finset.sum univ (id fun {n : ℕ} => n)` feels like a more realistic test
I see, I wasn't aware it would eagerly apply implicits in this way

I mean like realistic in the sense of something someone will be applying positivity to. Its nice to be feature complete but I'm not sure how much time I want to spend fixing things that will never come up in practice, at the moment its still not clear to me whether the issue you're pointing out is a real issue for this tactic or not
My example was more to demonstrate that this approach seems somewhat fishy; it's fine for positivity to not support these cases, but it should never produce invalid proof terms.
What if `body` is positive but `so` is `none`; don't we still want to prove that the sum is non-negative?
Fixed. It makes the extension longer but hopefully more robust.
Isn't the failure unreachable here? You never return `non` from the `do` block
Changing the definition style is slightly annoying to review but I suppose it's better this way.
This part of the diff belongs in #10538

Might as well delete this section entirely now.
```suggestion
```
This part of the diff belongs in #10538
Could you move these to a separate test file?
Please revert the merge of the `Finset.prod` part. One PR at a time :)
Now in #10538
I feel like this should be its own definition, since I can imagine there are lots more usecases for checking that a finset is not empty. Maybe even an `aesop` ruleset?
I don't really know how to set up an aesop ruleset, so it's a TODO for now.
Should we do these in the other order? I'd argue that finding the assumption is faster than a typeclass search, and so we should try it first.
Can you split all these generalizations to their own PR? It's best not to mix refactors and meta code.

why not:
```suggestion
      pure $ .positive q(prod_pos fun i _ ↦ $pr i)
```
Because there is a bug in `assertInstancesCommute` that makes it loop when you have several unnamed assumptions in your local context. Added a TODO and worked around it but we should open an issue.
I opened https://github.com/leanprover-community/quote4/issues/38.

```suggestion
    let rbody ← core zα pα body
    -- TODO: We must name the following, else `assertInstancesCommute` loops.
    let _instαmon ← synthInstanceQ q(CommMonoidWithZero $α)
    let _instαzeroone ← synthInstanceQ q(ZeroLEOneClass $α)
    let _instαposmul ← synthInstanceQ q(PosMulStrictMono $α)
    let _instαnontriv ← synthInstanceQ q(Nontrivial $α)
    let _instαnozerodiv ← synthInstanceQ q(NoZeroDivisors $α)
    assertInstancesCommute
    -- Try to show that the sum is positive
    try
      let .positive pbody := rbody | failure -- Fail if the body is not provably positive
      let pr : Q(∀ i, 0 < $f i) ← mkLambdaFVars #[i] pbody
      pure $ .positive q(prod_pos fun i _ ↦ $pr i)
    -- Try to show that the sum is nonnegative
    catch _ => try
      let pbody ← rbody.toNonneg
      let pr : Q(∀ i, 0 ≤ $f i) ← mkLambdaFVars #[i] pbody
      pure $ .nonnegative q(prod_nonneg fun i _ ↦ $pr i)
    catch _ =>
      let pbody ← rbody.toNonzero
      let pr : Q(∀ i, $f i ≠ 0) ← mkLambdaFVars #[i] pbody
      pure $ .nonzero q(prod_ne_zero fun i _ ↦ $pr i)
```
moving to earlier and deduplicating makes the tests still work locally: is this a reasonable change?

What I can see that might fail is if some of those `synthInstanceQ` commands fails only in the `catch`, but then maybe there should be a test against that.

Note: I have no experience of working with `Qq`, so feel free to give profuse comments about why this is a bad idea for my own edification!

Update: the suggested changes pass CI.

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8168589642/job/22330941550

> What I can see that might fail is if some of those `synthInstanceQ` commands fails only in the `catch`, but then maybe there should be a test against that.

I'm not sure this is what you meant, but indeed your version has a problem if the body is strictly positive but multiplication isn't strictly monotone. I have now added a test that works with my version but not yours.
Ok, this is exactly what I meant, thanks!

This `TODO` (and the similar ones below) does not actually indicate what should be done. Is the task to fix `Qq` so that the explicit naming is not necessary? Is there a github issue that you can link to?
I haven't yet decided. Please give your input here: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9365#discussion_r1500378763

```suggestion
      -- TODO (quote4#38): We must name the following, else `assertInstancesCommute` loops.
```

Apparently we can get rid of the `()` around the `do` blocks, but not the `:=` in front of `←`. 🤷‍♀️ (It seems you *can* get rid of the `:=`s if you really want, but only if you also turn the `return`s into `pure <|` and give all the `if`s `else`s...no preference here though.)
```suggestion
    let p_pos : Option Q(0 < $e) := ← do
      let .positive pbody := rbody | pure none -- Fail if the body is not provably positive
      -- TODO: We must name the following, else `assertInstancesCommute` loops.
      let .some _instαzeroone ← trySynthInstanceQ q(ZeroLEOneClass $α) | pure none
      let .some _instαposmul ← trySynthInstanceQ q(PosMulStrictMono $α) | pure none
      let .some _instαnontriv ← trySynthInstanceQ q(Nontrivial $α) | pure none
      assertInstancesCommute
      let pr : Q(∀ i, 0 < $f i) ← mkLambdaFVars #[i] pbody
      return some q(prod_pos fun i _ ↦ $pr i)
    -- Try to show that the product is positive
    if let some p_pos := p_pos then return .positive p_pos
    let p_nonneg : Option Q(0 ≤ $e) := ← do
      let .some pbody := rbody.toNonneg
        | return none -- Fail if the body is not provably nonnegative
      let pr : Q(∀ i, 0 ≤ $f i) ← mkLambdaFVars #[i] pbody
      -- TODO: We must name the following, else `assertInstancesCommute` loops.
      let .some _instαzeroone ← trySynthInstanceQ q(ZeroLEOneClass $α) | pure none
      let .some _instαposmul ← trySynthInstanceQ q(PosMulMono $α) | pure none
      assertInstancesCommute
      return some q(prod_nonneg fun i _ ↦ $pr i)
```
Maybe this whole block can be moved to a separate definition? It's a long definition anyway.
Sorry what do you mean, @Vierkantor ? It's two separate blocks
Sorry, I misparsed the code. I think we can format this a bit better though.

This is minor, but there is something we could do here to slightly reduce the proof term size. If, instead of `fun i _ ↦ $pr i`, we simply abstract the constant argument to `fun` during `mkLambdaFVars`, then we can use `$pr` directly:
```lean
      let m : Q($i ∈ $s) ← mkFreshExprMVarQ q($i ∈ $s) .syntheticOpaque
      let pr : Q(∀ (i) (_ : i ∈ $s), 0 < $f i) ← mkLambdaFVars #[i, m] pbody
      return some q(prod_pos $pr)
```
(This is exactly the same change for all three cases. We could of course hoist `let m ...` to the top of `evalFinsetProd`; I just put it here for demonstration.)

However, I'm not sure if (1) proof term size is important for `positivity` like it is for e.g. `norm_num` and (2) if the cost of abstracting outweighs the reduction. I'd be curious what a !bench would result in. (Does !bench support something like "!bench against <commit>" yet, or would you need to do it once before the change and once after?) Though, I won't hold up this PR if you'd rather not pursue this (either the benching or the edit itself). :)
My lambda handling skills are very shaky, so I would rather not risk editing it. Regardless, I doubt you could catch such an inconsequential difference in a benchmark

(Just given that the style guidelines now [say](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#whitespace-and-delimiters) `$` is disallowed in mathlib...sorry, I know you like `$`...😅)
```suggestion
    · exact (p.1.le_opNorm m).trans (mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right (norm_fst_le p) <| by positivity)
    · exact (p.2.le_opNorm m).trans (mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right (norm_snd_le p) <| by positivity)
```

```suggestion
    (H m).trans (mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right (le_max_left _ _) <| by positivity)
```

```suggestion
  ContinuousMultilinearMap.opNorm_le_bound _ (le_max_right _ _) fun m ↦ (H m).trans <|
    mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right (le_max_left _ _) <| by positivity
```
Is this the `compareHyp` issue? Should there be a `TODO` here somehow referring to the `TODO` about `compareHyp`? (Maybe not, I'm not sure what the standard is.)

Kinda? This particular case is a bit scope-creepy in that some random assumption in the context needs to be fed an argument to become a positivity hypothesis. It's not the same as wanting to derive `0 ≤ ∑ i in s, f i` from an `∀ i ∈ s, 0 ≤ f i` assumption. If it were the latter, we might want a todo, but here I don't think it warrants one.

```suggestion
      exact mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right (b_bound n m N hn hm) <| by positivity
```

```suggestion
      apply mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right _ <| by positivity
```

```suggestion
      exact mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right (b_bound n m n le_rfl hm) <| by positivity
```

```suggestion
    _ ≤ ‖f‖ * ‖m 0‖ * ∏ i, ‖tail m i‖ := mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right (f.le_opNorm _) <| by positivity
```

```suggestion
          _ ≤ (∏ i : Fin n, |R i|) * C := mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_left (hf _) <| by positivity
```

I guess we should make the `BinderInfo` `.default` instead of `.implicit`, otherwise we're technically lying to `Qq`. (We get away with it because `Qq` just happily constructs the `.app` believing it to be a `.default` binder, I think. I'm...actually not sure if this could *ever* cause an issue? But just to be safe...)

(This goes for the other 2 uses of `mkLambdaFVars` as well, ofc.)
```suggestion
      let pr : Q(∀ i, 0 < $f i) ← mkLambdaFVars #[i] pbody (binderInfoForMVars := .default)
```
(Not to be fixed in this PR but:) It's somewhat surprising that the default binder info is not `.default`!
That's indeed a strange choice of default!

Let's split up the different proof approaches into their own visual section and start each with their own comment.
```suggestion

    -- Try to show that the product is positive
    let p_pos : Option Q(0 < $e) := ← do
      let .positive pbody := rbody | pure none -- Fail if the body is not provably positive
      -- TODO(quote4#38): We must name the following, else `assertInstancesCommute` loops.
      let .some _instαzeroone ← trySynthInstanceQ q(ZeroLEOneClass $α) | pure none
      let .some _instαposmul ← trySynthInstanceQ q(PosMulStrictMono $α) | pure none
      let .some _instαnontriv ← trySynthInstanceQ q(Nontrivial $α) | pure none
      assertInstancesCommute
      let pr : Q(∀ i, 0 < $f i) ← mkLambdaFVars #[i] pbody (binderInfoForMVars := .default)
      return some q(prod_pos fun i _ ↦ $pr i)
    if let some p_pos := p_pos then return .positive p_pos

    -- Try to show that the product is nonnegative
    let p_nonneg : Option Q(0 ≤ $e) := ← do
      let .some pbody := rbody.toNonneg
        | return none -- Fail if the body is not provably nonnegative
      let pr : Q(∀ i, 0 ≤ $f i) ← mkLambdaFVars #[i] pbody (binderInfoForMVars := .default)
      -- TODO(quote4#38): We must name the following, else `assertInstancesCommute` loops.
      let .some _instαzeroone ← trySynthInstanceQ q(ZeroLEOneClass $α) | pure none
      let .some _instαposmul ← trySynthInstanceQ q(PosMulMono $α) | pure none
      assertInstancesCommute
      return some q(prod_nonneg fun i _ ↦ $pr i)
    if let some p_nonneg := p_nonneg then return .nonnegative p_nonneg

    -- Fall back to showing that the product is nonzero
    let pbody ← rbody.toNonzero
    let pr : Q(∀ i, $f i ≠ 0) ← mkLambdaFVars #[i] pbody (binderInfoForMVars := .default)
    -- TODO(quote4#38): We must name the following, else `assertInstancesCommute` loops.
    let _instαnontriv ← synthInstanceQ q(Nontrivial $α)
    let _instαnozerodiv ← synthInstanceQ q(NoZeroDivisors $α)
    assertInstancesCommute
    return .nonzero q(prod_ne_zero fun i _ ↦ $pr i)
```

(Lean 3 copypasta?)
```suggestion
/-- The `positivity` extension which proves that `∀ i, f i` is nonnegative if `f` is, and
```
Ah, certainly not! You are confusing `Π` and `∏`
Ah, right... 😆

Love how much can be replaced with `by positivity` due to this PR! :)

This review is shorter than it appears: almost all of these 12 comments are about `$`, with only a couple potentially "meaningful" review comments.
